title: How to Copy Files to an External Hard Drive: Quick & Easy Steps

steps.title: Determine the connection type for the hard drive and your computer.
steps.content: Determine the connection type for the hard drive and your computer. Most external hard drives use a USB cable to connect to your computer, but you may find that your computer doesn't have a USB-A port (the typical rectangular port). Mac computers and some Windows computers use oval USB-C ports instead of traditional USB-A ports. [1] X Research source Likewise, it's good to know if your external hard drive uses a USB-C cable when your computer only has USB-A ports. You can buy an adapter if needed. If your computer has a USB-C port instead of a USB-A port, you'll need to buy a USB-C to USB-A adapter for your computer. You can find these online and in some tech stores (e.g. Best Buy).

steps.title: Plug one end of the external hard drive's cable into your computer.
steps.content: Plug one end of the external hard drive's cable into your computer. This will usually be the USB end of the cable. USB-A connectors only fit one way, so don't force it if it doesn't fit; instead, rotate it 180 degrees and try connecting it again. USB-C connectors can be inserted in either orientation. If you're using an adapter, first connect the end of the adapter that fits in your computer to your computer, then plug the end of the external hard drive's cable into the free end of the adapter.

steps.title: Attach the other end of the cable to the external hard drive.
steps.content: Attach the other end of the cable to the external hard drive. Depending on the external hard drive, the cable may already be attached; if not, attach the free end of the cable to the port into which it fits on the external hard drive.

steps.title: Format your hard drive
steps.content: Format your hard drive if necessary. Depending on both the external hard drive and your computer's operating system, you may not be able to use your drive until you change its format to work with your computer. [2] X Research source Both Windows and Mac users can select exFAT as the file system when formatting the drive. This is ideal if you want to use your hard drive with both Windows and Mac computers. Formatting an external hard drive will erase everything on it.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . Click the File Explorer app icon, which resembles a yellow and blue folder, in your computer's task bar at the bottom of the screen. Copying files to an external drive is a great way to backup your information and free up disk space . If you don't see the File Explorer app icon here, you can open File Explorer by pressing ⊞ Win + E . [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source This method works for any type of external drive (hard drives, solid state drives, USB flash drives, SD cards).

steps.title: Go to the folder where your files are.
steps.content: Go to the folder where your files are. Using the left-hand panel of options, go to the folder where you have the files you want to copy to the external hard drive. For example, if your files are in the Documents folder, you would click Documents on the left to open the Documents folder.

steps.title: Highlight the files you want to copy.
steps.content: Highlight the files you want to copy. To do so, click and drag your mouse cursor across the contents of the folder. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source You can also hold down Ctrl and click each file you want to copy to select them individually. To highlight everything in a given folder, press Ctrl + A .

steps.title: Press Ctrl+C to copy the files.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + C to copy the files. This will allow you to copy the files to your external drive. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click This PC.
steps.content: Click This PC . It's on the left side of the File Explorer window.

steps.title: Double-click your external hard drive's name.
steps.content: Double-click your external hard drive's name. You'll see it below the "Devices and drives" heading in the middle of the page. If you don't see anything below the "Devices and drives" heading, click the heading to expand it. If you can't find your external hard drive here, try using a different USB slot for your hard drive.

steps.title: Paste in your files.
steps.content: Paste in your files. Click a blank space in the external hard drive's window, then press Ctrl + V to paste in the copied files. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Wait for your files to finish copying onto the drive.
steps.content: Wait for your files to finish copying onto the drive. Depending on your files' sizes, this process time will vary. You'll see a small window showing you the progress and estimated time remaining.

steps.title: Remove your hard drive
steps.content: Remove your hard drive . Once your files are done copying to the hard drive, safely ejecting your hard drive will ensure that no files are lost or corrupted: [7] X Research source Click in the lower-right side of the screen in the taskbar. Right-click the flash drive icon in the pop-up menu. Click the Eject option. Disconnect your external hard drive.

steps.title: Open Finder.
steps.content: Open Finder. Click the Finder app icon, which resembles a blue face, in your Mac's Dock. [8] X Research source This method works for any type of external drive (hard drives, solid state drives, USB flash drives, SD cards). You can check your hard drive space before copying files over if needed.

steps.title: Highlight the files you want to copy.
steps.content: Highlight the files you want to copy. Open the folder where you keep your files, then click and drag your mouse cursor across the contents of the folder. You can also hold down ⌘ Command and click each file you want to copy to select them individually. If you can't find your files, click All My Files on the left side of the Finder window to browse all of your Mac's folders.

steps.title: Click the Edit menu item.
steps.content: Click the Edit menu item. It's in the upper-left corner of your Mac's screen.

steps.title: Click Copy.
steps.content: Click Copy . This option is in the Edit drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click your external hard drive's name.
steps.content: Click your external hard drive's name. You'll find it below the "Devices" heading on the left side of the Finder window. Doing so opens your hard drive's window in the Finder. If you can't find your external hard drive here, try using a different USB slot for your hard drive.

steps.title: Click the Edit menu item again.
steps.content: Click the Edit menu item again. The drop-down menu will reappear.

steps.title: Click Paste Items.
steps.content: Click Paste Items . This will begin copying your selected files onto your external drive.

steps.title: Wait for your files to finish copying.
steps.content: Wait for your files to finish copying. Depending on your files' sizes, this process time will vary. You'll see a small window showing you the progress and estimated time remaining.

steps.title: Click the "Eject" button.
steps.content: Click the "Eject" button. It's an upward-facing arrow to the right of your hard drive's name in Finder. Doing so ensures that you can remove your hard drive without risking file loss or corruption. [9] X Research source Once you see the external hard drive's name disappear from the Finder side pane, you can physically disconnect it from your Mac.
